title: Kathmandu shareholder Briscoe searching for deals in Australia
text:
Briscoe's stake in Kathmandu has been diluted to 16 per cent from almost 20 per cent, but its total investment over the years has increased to $88 million.

"We're pretty happy sitting there at that level - there is nothing more I could do with 19 per cent than 16 per cent anyway," Mr Duke said.

Briscoe, which has 90 Briscoes and Rebel Sport stores in New Zealand, attempted to take over Kathmandu in 2015 as part of a strategy to expand into Australia, but the $324 million cash and scrip takeover bid failed.

A merger would have created a trans-Tasman retail group with sales of more than $900 million and 225 stores selling a range of goods from furniture and homewares, to sporting goods and apparel, and outdoor clothing and camping equipment.

However, Kathmandu shareholders denounced the proposed offer as opportunistic and indicated they would be reluctant to swap shares in the outdoor clothing retailer for shares in a small, illiquid New Zealand retailer which was at the time 80 per cent owned by Australian-born Mr Duke.

Briscoe responded to investors' reservations by listing in Australia in July 2017, but never made a second offer for Kathmandu and has been sitting on a near 20 per cent stake for four years.

Over that time Kathmandu shares have risen from Briscoe's average buy-in price of about $1.60 to $2.89. Canaccord Genuity analyst Benn Skender believes the shares could be worth $4.25 when the Rip Curl acquisition is bedded down.

Mr Duke, who owns 77 per cent of Briscoe, said the Australian listing had been worthwhile, even if Briscoe had yet to make an acquisition here.

Advertisement

"When we spoke to institutions in 2015 and 2016, a number showed some real interest but they were not mandated to invest in any stocks not listed in Australia," he said.

"Strategically it's a clever move if we have visions of expanding in the region."

Briscoe's first-half sales rose 3.3 per cent to $NZ302.98 million but net profit was flat at $NZ29.41 million as gross margins came under pressure from increased competition, the weaker New Zealand dollar and a late start to winter.

The group earned $NZ1.71 million in dividends from its stake in Kathmandu.
description: Four years after its unsuccessful takeover offer for Kathmandu, New Zealand retailer Briscoe Group is looking for acquisitions in Australia.
